'''Dan Sane''' (September 22, 1896<ref>Other sources cite 1904 as his birth year - they also cite Michigan, Mississippi (sic) as the birth place, which may invalidate the accuracy of the information.</ref> – February 18, 1956) was an [[United States|American]] [[Memphis blues|Memphis]] and [[country blues]] [[guitarist]] and [[songwriter]].<ref name="AMG"/> He was a working associate of [[Frank Stokes (musician)|Frank Stokes]] and, according to [[Allmusic]] [[music journalism|journalist]], Jason Ankeny, "they had emerged among the most complementary duos in all of the blues, with Sane's flatpicking ideally embellished by Stokes' fluid rhythms."<ref name="AMG"/> The best known of Sane's penned songs were "Downtown Blues" and "Mr. Crump Don't Like It." His surname was alternatively spelt as 'Sain'.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Samuel Barclay
| last= Charters
| year= 1977
| title= Sweet as the showers of rain
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Oak Publications 
| location= Indiana University
| isbn= 0-8256-0178-9
| page= 60}}</ref>

==Biography==
Sane was born in [[Hernando, Mississippi]].<ref name="Russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X
| page= 169}}</ref> He moved to [[Memphis, Tennessee]], and played in Will Batts' [[string band]],<ref name="AMG"/> before meeting guitar player [[Frank Stokes (musician)|Frank Stokes]]. Sane and Stokes [[busking|busked]] together around Memphis' [[Beale Street]] at weekends.<ref name="Russell"/> During the 1920s the pair performed on 
Beale Street as a [[duet (music)|duo]] billed as the Beale Street Sheiks and played in [[white people|white]] venues, including [[country club]]s, parties and dances, as members of Jack Kelly's Jug Busters.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Herzhaft">{{cite book
| first= Gérard
| last= Herzhaft
| year= 1997
| title= Encyclopedia of the blues
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= University of Arkansas Press 
| location= Fayetteville
| isbn= 1-55728-452-0
| page= 134}}</ref><ref name=hellhound/> Their first [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] was for [[Paramount Records]] in August 1927, under the Beale Street Sheiks name.<ref name="Russell"/> A [[National Park Service]]'s tourist guide to the blues heritage of the [[Mississippi Delta]] says: "The fluid guitar interplay between Stokes and Sane, combined with a propulsive beat, witty lyrics, and Stokes's stentorian voice, make their recordings irresistible."<ref name=hellhound>[http://www.cr.nps.gov/delta/blues/people/frank_stokes.htm 'Trail of the Hellhound: Frank Stokes'], U.S. National Park Service, Mississippi Delta Region, April 30, 2001. Accessed October 28, 2010.</ref> 

They moved to [[Victor Records]] in 1928, where the recordings were under Stokes' own name.<ref name="Russell"/> They recorded a two-part version of "[[Ain't Nobody's Business|Tain't Nobody's Business If I Do]]", a song well known in later versions by [[Bessie Smith]] and [[Jimmy Witherspoon]], but whose origin lies somewhere in the pre-blues era.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.document-records.com/fulldetails.asp?ProdID=DOCD-5013 |title=Frank Stokes The Victor Recordings 1928 - 1929 - Document Records Vintage Blues and Jazz |publisher=Document-records.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref> A locally popular song was "Mr. Crump Don't Like It," whose lyrics referred to Memphis mayor  [[E. H. Crump]] and his campaign to clean up Memphis' less salubrious areas. That song may have been based on an earlier song on the same topic by [[W. C. Handy]].<ref name="Russell"/><ref>{{cite book
| first= G. Wayne
| last= Dowdy
| year= 2006
| title= Mayor Crump Don't Like It: Machine Politics in Memphis
| edition= 1st
| publisher= University Press of Mississippi 
| location= United States 
| isbn= 1-57806-859-2
| page= 102}}</ref> The Sheiks also continued to busk the streets, and play informally at parties.

In 1929, Stokes and Sane recorded again for Paramount, resuming their 'Beale Street Sheiks' billing for a few cuts.<ref name="Russell"/> These 1929 sides were their last together, although Sane and Stokes continued their intermittent performing partnership up to the latter's retirement from music in 1952.<ref name="AMG"/> 

In 1933, Sane and Batts (1904–1956), alongside Kelly, recorded as the South Memphis Jug Band.<ref name="Russell"/><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://theanthologyofamericanfolkmusic.blogspot.com/2010/09/cold-iron-bed-jack-kelly-his-south.html |title=Where Dead Voices Gather: Life at 78 RPM: "Cold Iron Bed" - Jack Kelly & His South Memphis Jug Band |publisher=Theanthologyofamericanfolkmusic.blogspot.com |date=2010-09-13 |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref>

Sane died in Memphis in February 1956, aged 59.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=dan-sane-p121930/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Dan Sane |author=Ankeny, Jason |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 28, 2010}}</ref>

His guitar playing contributions have appeared on numerous [[compilation album]]s, including ''The Best of Frank Stokes'' ([[Yazoo Records]], 2005).<ref>{{cite web|author=Bruce Eder |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-best-of-frank-stokes-mw0000705329 |title=The Best of Frank Stokes - Frank Stokes | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2005-01-25 |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref>
